Article Modulating the microenvironment structure of single Zn atom: ZnN4P/C active site for boosted oxygen reduction reaction Syed Shoaib Ahmad Shah a b Tayyaba Najam a c * Jiao Yang a Muhammad Sufyan Javed d Lishan Peng a e f # Zidong Wei a $ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China b Key Laboratory of Luminescence Analysis and Molecular Sensing, Ministry of Education, School of Materials and Energy, Southwest University, Chongqing 400715, China Key Laboratory of Luminescence Analysis and Molecular Sensing Ministry of Education School of Materials and Energy Southwest University Chongqing 400715 China Key Laboratory of Luminescence Analysis and Molecular Sensing, Ministry of Education, School of Materials and Energy, Southwest University, Chongqing 400715, China c College of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, Guangdong, China College of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering Shenzhen University Shenzhen Guangdong 518060 China College of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, Guangdong, China d School of Physical Science and Technology, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China School of Physical Science and Technology Lanzhou University Lanzhou Gansu 730000 China School of Physical Science and Technology, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China e School of Chemical Sciences, The University of Auckland, Auckland 1142, New Zealand School of Chemical Sciences The University of Auckland Auckland 1142 New Zealand School of Chemical Sciences, The University of Auckland, Auckland 1142, New Zealand f Ganjiang Innovation Academy, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Ganzhou 341100, Jiangxi, China Ganjiang Innovation Academy Chinese Academy of Sciences Ganzhou Jiangxi 341100 China Ganjiang Innovation Academy, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Ganzhou 341100, Jiangxi, China * Corresponding author # Corresponding author $ Corresponding author The electronic structure of catalytic active sites can be influenced by modulating the coordination bonding of the central single metal atom, but it is difficult to achieve. Herein, we reported the single Zn-atom incorporated dual doped P, N carbon framework (Zn-N4P/C) for ORR via engineering the surrounding coordination environment of active centers. The Zn-N4P/C catalyst exhibited comparable ORR activity (E 1/2 = 0.86 V) and significantly better ORR stability than that of Pt/C catalyst. It also shows respectable performance in terms of maximum peak power density (249.6 mW cm−2), specific capacitance (779 mAh g−1), and charge-discharge cycling stability for 150 hours in Zn-air battery. The high catalytic activity is attributed to the uniform active sites, tunable electronic/geometric configuration, optimized intrinsic activity, and faster mass transfer during ORR-pathway. Further, theoretical results exposed that the Zn-N4P configuration is more electrochemically active as compared to Zn-N4 structure for the oxygen reduction reaction. Graphical abstract The microenvironment modulation of Zn single atom catalysts by P-doping enhanced the catalytic performance of single atoms for ORR and Zn-air battery by altering the electronic structure of central metal atom. Keywords N-, P-doping Oxygen reduction reaction Zn-air battery Single-atom catalyst Microenvironment modulation 1 Introduction The current energy crisis motivated researchers to cultivate alternate energy conversion and storage devices. The fuel cells and metal-air batteries are emerging devices due to their high-power densities and easy operation. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is the most critical step, which limited the performance of fuel cells as well as metal-air batteries due to its sluggish kinetics. Though the Pt and Pt–based electrocatalysts showed good performance, the scarcity and poor stability are the limiting factors [1]. It's urgent to explore Pt-free catalysts with high ORR performance to commercialize the metal-air batteries and fuel cells. The transition metal-coordinated N-doped carbon (M-N-C) catalysts have been explored as promising alternates, including the Fe-N-C, Co-N-C, Mn-N-C, and Zn-N-C, etc. [4,5]. Though the Fe-N-C showed ORR activity comparable to that of Pt, they typically have less stability during long-time operation [5]. The single atom catalysts (SACs) are finding increasing interest for electrocatalysis owing to their sufficient active sites with almost a hundred percent metal utilization [6–10]. The electronic and geometric configurations of SACs greatly depend upon their distinct atomic microenvironment modulation (MEM) including local coordination environment and electronic state of catalytic center [11–13]. Therefore, the activity, selectivity and durability of SACs are directly linked to their MEM system. However, due to lack of structural tailorability and precision in traditional synthetic methods, it remains a great challenge to synthesize a suitable MEM in catalytic active sites with enhanced performance. Recently, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have been attracting much attentions due to their characteristic properties including the high porosity, high surface area and structural diversity [14–18]. The atomic distribution of metal atoms on carbon support can be obtained by pyrolysis of MOFs and Zn based MOFs are usually considered as favorable precursors [19,20]. Due to the less boiling point of Zn (907 °C), SACs can be easily synthesized without agglomeration forming the metal-coordinated N-doped carbon (M-N x -C) [21,22]. Hence, MOF-derived SACs can ultimately inherit their high surface area/porosity and develop strong interaction between metal atoms and substrate [23,24]. The heteroatom-doped carbon materials have displayed promising electrocatalytic applications including ORR, and the ORR activity has been credited to the difference in electronegativity, charge polarization and electronic spin of carbon and other heteroatoms (S, P, N, F, B) [25–28]. This charge re-distribution by incorporating the heteroatoms also influence the electronic structure of metal atoms resulting the improved ORR performance by stretching O=O bond [29–32]. Further, incorporation of the heteroatoms can also modulate the electronic structure of SACs via strong electronic coupling [30]. The doping of multi-heteroatoms may have more influence on modulating the coordination sphere of SACs and thus improve the intrinsic activity and stability of the optimized active sites [33–36]. Extensive efforts have been carried out to modulate microenvironment of SACs [37–40]. However, the microenvironment behavior and the structure-activity relationship of catalysts remain largely elusive. Therefore, the atomically distinct microenvironment and exact identification of active sites may portray strong indication to disclose the influence of MEM on the catalytic performance in ORR. Herein, the microenvironment modulation strategy is reported to fabricate Zn based single atom sites supported on the P, N dual-doped carbon (Zn-N4P/C) for ORR. The experimental and computational results suggest that single Zn atoms stabilized by four N-coordination in P, N dual-doped carbon matrix are the actual active sites. The enhanced ORR performance is attributed to the creation of active sites via charge redistribution due to multi-heteroatom doping, which lowers the reducing potential barriers of the oxygen reduction reaction. Moreover, higher durability and more positive half-wave potential are attained on Zn-N4P/C than that of P-free controls and commercial Pt/C. When assembled as air-cathode in zinc-air battery, it shows respectable performance in terms of maximum peak power and energy densities. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of ZIF-8 3 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 80 mL of methanol then 80 mL of methanolic solution containing 6.5 g of 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIM) was mixed by stirring one hour, followed by 24 h incubation at room temperature. The white powder of ZIF-8 was centrifuged, washed several times with methanol and dried at 60 °C in oven. 2.2 Synthesis of ZnN4/C For the synthesis of ZnN4/C, the as prepared ZIF-8 was carbonized at 900 °C for 2 h. under Ar/H2 atmosphere. The black sample was used without further treatment. 2.3 Synthesis of ZnN4P/C For the fabrication of ZnN4P/C, 0.1 g of ZnN4/C was added into 20 mL of solution (water:ethanol) and sonicated for 15 min. Then, 4 mL of phytic acid solution (50%) was poured in the suspension and stirred for 12 h. The sample was collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol and dried in oven. The collected sample was carbonized in Ar/H2 atmosphere for 1 h at 900 °C to produce ZnN4P/C. The details about electrochemical measurements, structural characterization, and theoretical calculations are in the Supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The synthesis method for the preparation of Zn-N4P/C is given in Scheme 1 . Firstly, Zn-NC is prepared through the controllable pyrolysis of Zn-MOF. During the first carbonization step, Zn is evaporated leaving the Zn-single atoms on the NC surface [12,33]. Then, the surrounding microenvironment of Zn active species (ZnN4/C) is tuned by adding phytic acid. The phytic acid has dual functionality such as; (1) P-source, (2) removal of inactive metal species, which tend to motivate in situ growth of ZnN4P/C porous/defective support during second heating. We have the first time induced the electronic structure modulations in Zn-single atom catalysts supported on P, N doped carbon matrices. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Zn-N4P/C and Zn-NC revealed a broad peak at about 24.3° that is assigned to (002) phase of amorphous carbon whereas no sharp peak was observed, suggesting the absence of Zn NPs and crystalline ZnP2 phase (Fig. S1). The Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images showed that the Zn-N4P/C sample inherited the typical polyhedron morphology of Zn-MOF morphology, whereas slight morphological changes occurred during the second pyrolysis for P-doping (Fig. S2) as the edges and corners become smooth. The high carbonization temperature decomposes the ZIF-8 crystals to form an interconnected N-doped carbon network. During the carbothermal reduction, the zinc ions are reduced to form Zn nanoparticles, which can be easily evaporated (low boiling point of Zn) revealing copious pores in produced N-doped carbon matrix. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images exposed the presence of amorphous structure along with the absence of any Zn-NPs and impure phases (Figs. 1(a), (b) ). In order to deeply understand the morphology of Zn-N4P/C, the aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) result indicated single Zn-atoms over the surface of P, N doped carbon matrix by showing single bright spots (Fig. 1(c)). The corresponding energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX) mapping as shown in Fig. 1(d) further confirmed the homogeneous distribution of Zn, C, N, and P in Zn-N4P/C sample. The high Zn-content of 6.8 wt% was determined by EDX analysis which is very close to the value obtained by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) result (i.e., 6.23 wt%, Table S1). The degree of graphitization was further monitored by the Raman spectroscopy and higher I G/I D value of ZnN4P/C than that of ZnN4/C indicated high graphitization in ZnN4P/C, which is capable to enhance the electronic conductivity to boost the ORR performance. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm showed comparatively higher BET surface area exhibited by ZnN4P/C (1049.3 m2/g) as compared to ZnN4/C (986.2 m2/g) as shown in Fig. 2(a) . Thus, indicating that the presence of ZnN4 species in P, N doped carbon, would successively provide adequate active sites and promotes the faster mass transfer during ORR-pathway [41,42]. Further, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to figure out the element composition of Zn-N4/C and Zn-N4P/C samples (Fig. S6). The XPS survey of Zn-N4P/C revealed the existence of C, N, P, and Zn, thus confirming the formation of heteroatom P, N doped catalyst with a high Zn-content of 3.6 wt% (Fig. S6 and Table S2). The high-resolution N1s spectra can be deconvoluted into five peaks related to pyridinic-N (398.2 eV), Zn-N x (399.4 eV), pyrrolic-N (399.9 eV), graphitic-N (401.2 eV), and N-oxide (402.3 eV) signals (Fig. S7). Notably, the intensity of pyrrolic-N peak is high in Zn-N4/C whereas the peak intensity of Zn-N x peak is high in Zn-N4P/C, indicating that more ZnN x active species are exposed to the surface after P-doping. Fig. S8 shows the C 1s spectrum of ZnN4/C was categorized as three main peaks, i.e., graphitic sp 2 carbon (C=C), N coordinated with carbon (C–N), O=C–O signals. While an additional peak of P coordinated with carbon (C-P) was found in Zn-N4P/C sample representing the successful P-doping into carbon matrix. The P 2p spectrum shown in Fig. S9 presents a prominent peak of P-O (134.1 eV), indicating surface oxidation of Zn-N4P/C. The spin-orbit doublet peaks correspond to the peak signals P 2p 3/2, and P 2p 1/2 at about 129.9, and 131.4 eV. The higher binding energy of P 2p 1/2 peak indicated the existence of a partially negative charged P [30]. Thus, the electrons were transferred from C/N towards P due to its higher electronegativity during electrocatalysis. The high-resolution Zn 2p analysis of Zn-N4/C and Zn-N4P/C samples showed two prominent peaks at about 1045.6, 1022.4 eV, assigned to Zn 2p 1/2, Zn 2p 3/2 signals (Fig. 2(b)). The positive shift of 0.2 eV in the binding energy of Zn-N4P/C was observed as compared to Zn-N4/C, which might be responsible for creating a stabilization effect against the oxidation/dissolution of metallic species. Hence, all these results confirmed the successful fabrication of homogeneously dispersed Zn SACs with P and N sites embedded in the carbon matrix. In addition, X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements were performed to reveal the local structural information of the metal center. The Zn K-edge XANES (Fig. 2(c)) illustrates that the absorption threshold position in Zn-N4P/C sample is positively shifted compared with that of ZnPc and ZnO, indicating that the average valence state of Zn is higher than +2 [3]. The corresponding XANES derivative spectra as shown in Fig. S10, are used to fit the detail valence state of Zn. The location of the first peak in energy for the value of Zn foil and ZnO can be used as a reference, and the fitting result indicates the oxidation state of Zn in ZnN4P/C is 3.3. The prominent peak at ~1.5 Å associated with the Zn–N bonding in the Fourier transform (FT) k 2-weighted Zn K-edge EXAFS spectrum further confirmed the presence of Zn single atom in Zn-N4P/C (Fig. 2(d)). On the other hand, the absence of Zn-Zn (at R =2.2 Å) and Zn-P (at R =1.8 Å) also confirmed that Zn single atoms were only stabilized via N-coordination to form ZnN x active sites. Furthermore, the fitting EXAFS results suggested Zn-N4 structure is the prevailing structure in ZnN4P/C instead of Zn-Zn/ZnN2 moieties. The fitting of EXAFS (FT-EXAFS) spectra in R-space are shown in Fig. 2(e) and the EXAFS fitting parameters are listed in Table S3. The EXAFS parameters are calculated to extract the quantitative structural configuration for the atoms surrounding the central Zn-atom in Zn-N4P/C sample (Table S3) which confirmed the Zn-atom coordinated with nearly four nitrogen atoms. The elongation in Zn–N bond results presumably from the influence of P atoms in ZnN4P/C by directly forming neighboring N–P bonds. Further FT-EXAFS results indicated that one P atom and six C atoms exist in the second shell of Zn with a distance of 2.33 and 3.06 Å, respectively. The distance between Zn and P atom fits well with the predicted structure simulated by DFT calculation inserted in Fig. 2(e). The existence of P atoms located next to Zn-N4 moiety influence the Zn–N bond with a longer length by directly forming neighboring N–P bonds. Further, wavelet transforms (WT) for the k 3-weighted Zn K-edge EXAFS oscillations were performed for Zn-foil, ZnO, ZnPc, and ZnN4P/C samples to evaluate the atomic state of Zn-atom (Fig. 2(f)). The results confirmed the presence of Zn-N scattering path in ZnN4P/C sample by revealing only one peak with maximum intensity at about 3.9 Å−1, similar to ZnPc. On contrary, Zn-foil and ZnO samples displayed maximum peak intensities at 6.2 and 4.4 Å−1, assigned to Zn-Zn and Zn-O scattering paths. The contour intensity maximum for ZnN4P/C catalyst shifted slightly compared with that of ZnPc, which is ascribed to the influence of P-doping. Hence, these results confirmed the existence of highly dispersed isolated Zn-atoms fused with dual doped P, N-rich carbon framework. 3.2 Electrochemical performance The rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) test was used to monitor the catalytic performance of as-synthesized samples in 0.1 mol/L KOH. The Zn-N4P/C electrocatalyst showed comparable activity to that of Pt/C (20%) as shown in Fig. 3 . The similar E onset of 1.01 V, E 1/2 = 0.86 V and 5.14 mA cm−2 of diffusion limiting current density presented by Zn-N4P/C with respect to commercial Pt/C (5.42 mA cm−2), whereas ZnN4/C showed lower E onset of 0.81 V with 2.16 mA cm−2 of current density at 0.4 V (Fig. 3(a)). The result of Zn-N4P/C was also exceptional due to very low production of hydrogen peroxide (< 2%) as compared to ZnN4/C (12%) and Pt/C (> 3%) (Fig. 3(a)). Moreover, the Zn-N4P/C electrocatalyst showed an electron transferred number of ~3.9, calculated from RRDE data (Fig. 3(b)), indicating the efficient reduction of oxygen to water through a 4e− pathway. Further, the comparable kinetic current density exhibited by Zn-N4P/C with respect to Pt/C (Fig. 3(c)) while higher as compared to ZnN4/C. The enhanced catalytic performance of Zn-N4P/C was further confirmed by Tafel slope. Fig. 3(d) shows that the Zn-N4P/C has a Tafel slope of 81 mV dec−1, nearby to commercial Pt/ C (76 mV dec−1) and much less than ZnN4/C (142 mV dec−1). Hence, the electrocatalytic performance of Zn-N4P/C showed that Zn-SACs embedded in a dual-doped carbon framework improves the catalyst's activity and motivate the synergistic effect with N-C. These consequences indicated Zn-N4P/C as the best electrocatalyst among other synthesized catalysts and comparable to the commercial Pt/C. In addition, the durability test was investigated between 0.6–1.0 V (RHE) at 50 mV s−1 of sweep rate for 8000 CV cycles and confirmed the good durability of Zn-N4P/C by demonstrating a small ΔE 1/2 of 5 mV (Fig. 3(e)) than Pt/C (ΔE 1/2 of 20 mV). These features confirmed Zn-N4P/C as a good electrocatalyst for the ORR as compared to the reported SACs in the alkaline media (Table S4). On the basis of results, it can be concluded that structural changes that occur through P-doping lead to encourage the activity of ZnN4 species. Moreover, the P-doping can induce different charge distributions as compared to nitrogen due to its large atomic radius and high electron donating ability [38]. Hence, P-doping may assist the ORR process by inducing the carbon atoms with a positive charge to attract electrons and effectively deteriorate the O−O bonding [44–46]. Further, the as-synthesized catalyst without P-doping showed inferior performance, thus confirming the critical role of dual doping for enhanced ORR pathway. Therefore, the enriched ORR catalytic activity is credited to the synergism of single Zn single atoms and P, N doped carbon framework. Motivated by the superior ORR activity, the Zn-N4P/C was assembled to monitor Zn-air battery performance. Fig. 4(a) shows the peak power density of Zn-N4P/C at 249.6 mW cm−2, comparatively higher than that of Pt/C (227 mW cm−2). The comparative study of stability performance was carried out at various discharge voltages; that is from 5 to 50 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4(b)). The results indicated a significant increase in voltage gap with 2, 11, 36.7, 110.4 mV, suggesting the robust conductive nature of Zn-N4P/C at higher current densities. As shown in Fig. 4(c), Zn-N4P/C catalyst showed excellent stability during the galvanostatic charge/discharge at 10 mA cm−2 by retaining the charge-discharge voltage gap for 150 h. While, Pt/C showed the gradual performance loss with increased charge-discharge gap. The specific capacities calculated at 20 mA cm−2 for Zn-N4P/C, and Pt/C were 779, and 714 mAh g−1 (Fig. 4(d)). Further, the Zn-air battery assembled by the Zn-N4P/C electrode showed open circuit voltage of 1.49 V (Fig. S12) comparatively better than previously reported catalysts (Table S4). 3.3 Theoretical computation The ORR reaction mechanism and the phenomenon behind the activity enhancement was further explored by density functional theory (DFT) calculations based on the structural models for ZnN4/C and ZnN4P/C. The computational details are provided in supporting information. As shown in Figs. 5(a), (b) , the P bridged Zn-N4 moieties (Zn-N4-P) show improved electron density around the Zn atom (yellow region) than the basal plane-hosted Zn-N4 sites, indicating the redistribution of charge density on ZnN4P/C. The partial density of states (PDOS) study on ZnN4/C and ZnN4P/C indicated the slightly small negative shift in d bandgap (ɛ d) of Zn in ZnN4P/C than the Zn atoms in ZnN4/C, assuming the enhanced local electronic conductivity of Zn-N4 specie via P-doping (Fig. 5(b)). In addition, it was also confirmed that the fragile binding energy of adsorbates on P doped ZnN4 carbon. The corresponding five states of ZnN4/C and ZnN4P/C for Gibbs-free energy calculations, represented in Figs. S13 and S14. Further, the Gibbs free energy diagrams were calculated at U = 0 V (Fig. 5(d)) and U = 1.23 V (Fig. S15) towards ORR-pathway. As known, the last electron transfers step (*OH desorption) is considered as rate-determining step (RDS), representing that the weakening of Zn-O affinity is important for activity promotion. Therefore, adsorption and desorption properties were investigated on ZnN4/C and ZnN4P/C. The ZnN4P/C represented a much larger value of ΔG OH* (adsorption free-energy of *OH) than that of Zn-N4, endorsing the lower binding ability for the oxygen molecule and faster OH* desorption process. Further, the extremely high adsorption of *OH in Zn-N4/C results in a greater energy barrier for the last electron transfer step, whereas ZnN4P/C sample demonstrated well-regulated binding strength of *OH which ultimately reduces the energy barrier (Fig. 5(e)). The improved performance is attributed to the P-doping by reducing the adsorption capability of intermediate specie (*OH), finally assisting the dynamic improvement of ORR. 4 Conclusions In summary, successful fabrication of the single ZnN4 sites induced N, P doped carbon framework was synthesized by structural modulation strategy. The synergistic modulation on the electronic structure of zinc single-atom catalysts by the N/P coordination greatly enhanced its ORR performance. These findings showed; (1) the heteroatom doping and metallic sites on the carbon framework are key factors for improved catalytic performance, (2) the synergistic modulations can be adopted via facile synthesis method. The optimized ZnN4P/C catalyst showed comparatively higher ORR performance (E 1/2 = 0.861 V) as compared to ZnN4/C, and Pt/C (20%). Further, it shows superior activity by demonstrating maximum peak power density (249.6 mW cm−2), greater specific capacitance (779 mAh g− 1), and stable charge/discharge cycling performance operated at 10 mA cm−2 for 150 h, comparatively better than commercial Pt/C. Further, the DFT calculations revealed that the improved ORR performance can be attributed to the charge redistribution on ZnN4 active sites via P-doping with optimal O2 binding and fast electron transfer. Hence, this work shows optimal synthetic strategy for the microenvironment modulations in SACs for enhanced performance. coredata.dc:description: The electronic structure of catalytic active sites can be influenced by modulating the coordination bonding of the central single metal atom, but it is difficult to achieve. Herein, we reported the single Zn-atom incorporated dual doped P, N carbon framework (Zn-N4P/C) for ORR via engineering the surrounding coordination environment of active centers. The Zn-N4P/C catalyst exhibited comparable ORR activity (E 1/2 = 0.86 V) and significantly better ORR stability than that of Pt/C catalyst. It also shows respectable performance in terms of maximum peak power density (249.6 mW cm−2), specific capacitance (779 mAh g−1), and charge-discharge cycling stability for 150 hours in Zn-air battery. The high catalytic activity is attributed to the uniform active sites, tunable electronic/geometric configuration, optimized intrinsic activity, and faster mass transfer during ORR-pathway. Further, theoretical results exposed that the Zn-N4P configuration is more electrochemically active as compared to Zn-N4 structure for the oxygen reduction reaction.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Modulating the microenvironment structure of single Zn atom: ZnN4P/C active site for boosted oxygen reduction reaction
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2022 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
